The BFR was 110 meters tall, for comparison a standard MK3 fuel tank is 5 meters long. It have a diameter of 9 meters or something? When the MK3 parts are usually 3.5*3.8 meters for cross section. Hello Tim!

I've got you some help for propulsive landings. Check out the mod "Better Burn Time", it gives you very accurate suicide burn calculations.

10 meters per second is 22 miles per hour, coming to a complete stop from 22 miles per hour instantly has the tendency to break things. Even 5 meters per second to 0 in an instant is pretty aggressive.
A bit of scaling with tweakscale and you have yourself a full-size BFR/ITS

Those black engines you used for the booster stage are actually KSP's version of the space shuttle main engines. They even have the correct gimbal range (10°)!
Edit: This is also the reason why they are named "Vector".

Fins on rocket serve no purpose, right?
The fins on the SF rockets of the 50's, served two purposes; gave a wider landing
gear footprint; and if the landing gear fails, the fins could "crumple" and still kept
the rocket upright, without catastrophic failure. If the DC-XA had been designed
with fins, it would not have crashed, when the landing strut failed to extend due
to a disconnected hydraulic line. Where would we be now, if the DC-XA had not
crashed and burned?

I saw you on TMRO. Y'all got it wrong. Elon wasn't saying BFR is cheaper per kg. He is saying it is cheaper per launch. So that same satellite on the top of an F9 costs more than to launch it by itself on BFR. But then you launch 20 such satellites from 8 customers all at the same time on one BFR and now the cost per satellite is next to nothing.
